job_title: Admissions Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: I enjoyed working there a lot.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lofty (if ill-defined) goals. Many of the faculty truly care about the students and about contributing to a more just world.
cons: Woo-woo factor verges on the nonsensical. HR is a mess, the "self-service" platform is broken, and staff turnover is ridiculous. Salaries are below par.

review_title: Level of Compensation Getting Better but Still Struggling in Areas

pros: would have been able to do classes after a year of working full time

job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of support progressive thinking loving community

job_title: Facilities Manager in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Program Director in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Manager in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule (work life balance)

job_title: Associate Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: A unique, one of a kind place to work. Students are wonderful.
cons:
Salaries are low but the new leadership is working on it. 
Administrative infrastructure has been very messy over the years.

job_title: Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The program manager community is strong and supports one another.
cons: The administration is and the data system migration was a total mess. There is hope with the new president and provost, but it's going to take a lot to streamline the process.

job_title: Human Resources/Payroll Generalist in San Francisco, CA
pros: This place is with the opportunity
cons: not enough leadership opportunity if you are thinking to grow

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wonderful community that I loved being a part of.
cons: Management really doesn’t care too much about staff.

job_title: Program Manager in Oakland, CA
pros: Great people and great mission
cons: Below market pay (very below market)

review_title: Wonderful place to expand your horizons! We have an opportunity to create new and innovative approaches to higher ed.
job_title: Career and Community Engagement Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Meaningful conversations. Amazing, dynamic students. Important social perspectives. Critical education for social justice. Open access to opportunities to address my skill development gaps. Ability to work with senior leadership.
cons: It's true, the salary isn't great. But the benefits are pretty good. If you are here full-time for a year, you have access to tuition remission, major benefit if you want an advanced degree.

review_title: A Nice Place to Study, but a Non-Living Wage and Dead End Job for Staff
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule options, really nice people, politically left of center, free yoga if you can get the time off, generous time off after a few years.
cons: Extremely low, unrealistic payscale which equals a non-living wage to anyone who lives locally. No COLA. No raises. No 401K. Limited and expensive employee contribution to benefits. Promises but offers lack of opportunity for advancement. No support from upper management or HR. Staff structure does not support long-term career path which results in continual staff turnover and more work put on staff that stays. Staff morale is in the toilet.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The school is located in San Francisco, and the students who pay the outlandish tuition are dedicated, but highly stressed.
cons: The Institute is suffused with identity politics, political correctness, and new age ga-ga.  In contrast to the Institute's noble goals, the administration is shallow, money-oriented, concerned with popular opinion, and looks only to the bottom-line. Consequently, academic standards suffer. You dare not fail a student who contributes to the budget.

review_title: CIIS--a great place to work, but you won't get rich
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: CIIS provides an amazing community of people to work with, has an open style of leadership that values all employees, and does a great job in allowing that you have a life outside of work--you can bring your whole self to work here. It is more democratic than other places I have worked in that you have access to all levels of the leadership structure, and they will at least listen to you ideas. They do provide a very generous benefits package, and provide a more generous vacation package than you will find elsewhere. The benefits plan includes chiropractic and massage, and staff get additional time off over the winter holidays as the Institute closes for at least one week (and pays employees for those days).
cons: Because it is a non-profit, the salaries at CIIS are not on par with those of the private sector, including other educational institutions. It is also difficult to move up because the staffing is structured with a lot of dead-ends. Although almost everyone working at CIIS is a fascinating person with a rich life outside of work, sometimes they are TOO interesting and lack the advanced professional skills necessary to make such a lean operation run smoothly. Too many times one person can derail an entire project because they "don't get it" or don't agree. The flip-side of a very democratic structure is that one person or a few people can stall things, and this keeps the organization from progressing.

job_title: Student Services in San Francisco, CA
pros: Amazing coworkers who truly believe they can change the world.  A camaraderie that sets the bar for other institutions.
cons: Extreme lack of policies and procedures that pit departments against each other.  Entitled students who are even more insufferable when their paperwork isn't completed.  Little interest in making or enforcing rules.  They don't want to be "that kind of place" but their staff and students are suffering.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wonderful free thinking environment. Excellent vacation time benefits.  If you are not driven by a need to make a living wage this is an amazing place to work.
cons: Low pay and little opportunity to advance.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Interesting environment with creative thinkers and visionaries. Community oriented teams and great colleagues. Managers willing to help support staff to work on passion projects.
cons: Salary ranges and career development opportunities are limited.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great community. Important pioneering academics & mission. Flexible & understanding supervisors. Dedicated employees. A family.
cons: Non-profit budget and academic-minded community makes for inefficiencies; not unlike any university environment though. A family.

job_title: "Fellow" With Center for Writing and Scholarshi in San Francisco, CA
pros: compassion, commitment, supportive, personal growth, community
cons: As a Fellow, the number of hours one works each week varies, and therefore is hard to plan on monthly income when it fluctuates like this.

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great, caring people and cutting edge approach to integral education
cons: Exploitative salaries; no support for research; unclear advancement qualifications

job_title: Student Cafe Worker in San Francisco, CA
pros: fun team, great deal of independence, well structured work environment

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Oakland, CA
pros: Great people who come by and do amazing work.
cons: I would say that there really was none.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: flexible schedule and easy commute
cons: This is a cult like working environment and the management just seems to keep reproducing the personalities that lead to the creation of personal fiefdoms inside of departments.
